instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Hey guys, 

Recently a customer brought in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with a getting stuck periodically problem, after some cleaning around the ram slots and the ram themselves the machine worked properly for a couple of months and then was brought back with another issue. It had no image on the lcd. Works fine with an external monitor, charges, chimes etc.

While doing some measurements around the lcd connector area, i found out that <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is missing (?). I replaced <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> still no change.
<CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is supposed to be the ic generating that voltage right?
Am i just supposed to change that off a donor board or is there something else i should check first?
Already tried a different screen assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Post voltage for pins 4, 6, 7 of J9000.
Check trraces/solders at J9000 and connector itself.
Be sure L9010/11 are OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
L9010/9011 are fine, traces seem ok under the microscope, 

Pin 4 - 3.3v
Pin 6 - 3.3v
Pin 7 - 0.082v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message: Resistance to ground pins 6 & 7; diode mode, red probe to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Pin 6 - 0.52v
Pin 7 - 0.51v 
Same measurements with lcd connected and disconnected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message: I have done that already, its 100k?hm as its supposed to be according to the schematics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Measuring <RESISTOR>R9010</RESISTOR>/11 onboard, you must get similar reading.
Check integrity of <SIGNAL>LVDS_DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Ok i got something, i got some flux on the lvds connector, did some cold joints, now i got 3.3v on pin 7.
But still no image, pins 38-39-40 of j9000 got 0v. fuse seems fine , led drive on the other hand not so well, should just change all of that just in case?
Would really love to get something out of this though.
Knowledge wise ofc, because if i do  change all of it i wont have the information needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Any voltage at pins 2/3?
LCD must be connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Pin 2 - 0v
Pin 3 - 3.26v
Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR> - 0v
Pin 2 of L9000 - 0v.

Lcd connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
I think is better to change the LCD connector.
After removed, check all the traces, before soldering new one.
Pins 2 & 3 should have same voltage; both are tied together, as per schematic.
And if you get 3V there, image must be present; and <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> too.
In such case, you must repair backlight circuit only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Update, i changed the lcd connector still the same issue.
I even shorted the 2nd and 3d pins and the 2nd one still doesnt have 3.3v.
I m running out of ideas.. 
Is there any way this is a gpu issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message: The strange thing is that pin 3 has 3.3v but L9000 has no voltage, <CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR> nothing as well, traces from pin 2-3 to those are fine and they have continuity. I m getting the urge to send this in the garbage pile but this was brought on some sort of "warranty". Any ideas are welcome.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
Shouldn't be GPU issue, as external monitor is always driven by GPU.

"I even shorted the 2nd and 3d pins and the 2nd one still doesnt have 3.3v."
You did something wrong.
If both pins are tied together, cannot get different voltage.
Use boardview and identify the pins correctly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no lcd
threads.message:
That was my problem as well, but after some close inspection on the board, i found out that L8608 was missing, i put one there from a donor board and the machine booted up and is working properly. 
So it wasnt a matter of lcd connector, or doing something wrong. The voltages were the ones i described even though it made absolutely no sense. Anyhow, we can count this one as solved and hopefully it will help someone with the same issue. That L8606 is right in the middle of the board and apparently if you are not the one disassembling the machine, things can get knocked off.
Thank you for all your help.
